DeregistrationReasonOtherText: no longer has any Sulfur Dioxide or Sulfur Trioxide in inventory

_prev_prog_3.Description:
Process Safety Information ('68.65) - The process capacities are 3,781,260 lb of sulfur dioxide, 126,800 lb of sulfur trioxide, and 20,316,591 lb of oleum.  The MSDSs for these chemicals are available to all employees associated with the process.  The process is not only designed in compliance with good engineering practices and with Federal and state regulations, it is also maintained within safe operating ranges.

Process Hazard Analysis ('68.67) - The process hazard analysis (PHA) for Intertrade's Copperhill, TN facility indicates that the facility was properly designed and is following procedures which minimize the probability of a release. The elements of the PHA include those hazards associated with the chemicals use, equipment malfunctions, human errors that may result in an accidental release, safeguards to prevent accidental releases, and detection and monitoring steps. The PHA is performed by qualified personnel knowledgeable in the process and in the PHA methodology.

Operating Procedures ('68.69) - The process is operated by trained personnel using safe operating practices.  Specifically, there are written operating procedures for each operating phase including initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, normal shutdown, startup, correction of deviations and equipment inspections.  These written operating procedures are regularly reviewed and are readily accessible to the operators.

Training ('68.71) - All employees presently operating or assigned to the process have been trained or tested in the skills and duties necessary to safely operate the process.  Furthermore, all employees who are newly assigned to the process are thoroughly trained and tested proficient before operating the process.  A list of the trained employees is maintained.  Refresher training is provided at least every three years, or more frequently if needed to maintain safe operating practices.

Mechanical Integrity ('68.73) - All process equipment is properly inspected and serviced either by trained employees or maintenance contractors.  Any maintenance contractor shall ensure that each contract employee is properly trained in the maintenance procedures to be performed.  All identified equipment deficiencies are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

Management of Change ('68.75) - Written procedures are in place to manage process changes, including changes in equipment and procedures.  All personnel affected by these changes are promptly informed of the changes and trained to deal with the modification.

Pre-Startup Review ('68.77) - Whenever a change is made to the process necessitating a change in the process safety information, Intertrade confirms the completeness of the Prevention Program revision.  This includes confirming that a PHA has been performed for the correctly installed equipment, procedures are in place for operations, maintenance, and emergency response, and the employees trained in the new procedures.

Compliance Audits ('68.79) - The procedures and practices of the RMP Prevention Program for the process at Intertrade's Copperhill, TN facility comply with the requirements of 40 CFR 68 and are currently being followed.  Compliance audits are conducted at least every three years to determine if current procedures are appropriate and being followed.  The two most recent compliance audits that are less than 5 years old are available.

Incident Investigations ('68.81) - All incidents which resulted in or may have resulted in a catastrophic release are investigated in order to correct any safety deficiencies that have the potential to result in a future release. Investigations begin less than 48 hours after the occurrence of the incident.  The findings of the investigation are reviewed with all affected personnel and corrective action is taken to prevent future releases.  The summaries of all of the incident investigations from the past five years are available. 

Employee Participation ('68.83) - Intertrade's employees have participated in the development of the PHA, operating and maintenance procedures.  All employees are made aware of the hazards associated with the process, as well as the effort to assess and minimize the probability and effect of a release.    

Hot Work Permit ('68.85) - Intertrade has in place procedures to safely conduct hot work.  These include procedures for initiation, hot work area review, safe hot work methods, and fire watches.

Contractors ('68.87) - In order to minimize the risk associated with the use of contractors working on the process, Intertrade reviews the safety history of each potential contractor.  All contractors working on the process are informed of the process hazards and emergency procedures.  Procedures are in place to limit and control contractor movement on site.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Sulfur dioxide, sulfur trioxide, and oleum are stored and used on site by Intertrade at the Copperhill, TN facility in quantities that exceed the threshold quantities as defined by the Risk Management Program regulations.  Intertrade has diligently developed and implemented a comprehensive Risk Management Program, assessing the hazards associated with the process, as well as implementing procedures which minimize the the probability and severity of a release.

In the past five years there have been two minor releases, one involving oleum, and the other involving sulfur dioxide.  Since that time, process equipment has been changed to minimize the probability of a future release.  Furthermore, the facility complies with the EPA's accident prevention rule and all applicable state and local codes and regulations.

Our worst-case scenario is the unlikely failure of the sulfur dioxide pressure vessel during a time in which the maximum quantity is stored in it.  The resulting distance to the endpoint extends offsite, and public receptors are within the distance to the endpoint.  Our alternative release scenarios are piping breaks and small vessel leaks.  The resulting distance to the endpoint extends offsite, and public receptors are withihn the distance to the endpoint.  

In the event of an emergency involving the release of sulfur dioxide, sulfur trioxide, or oleum across plant boundaries, it is our policy to notify the East Polk Sherrifs Office and Fire Department, the Fannin County Fire Department and Sherrifs Office, the Polk County LEPC, and TEMA.  Due to the close proximity of the site location to the state borders of Georgia and North Carolina, TEMA and the Polk County LEPC may advise Intertrade to notify the North Carolina or Georgia LEPC.
